newsitem.title: UK: LME copper stops short of $2,300, others mixed.
newsitem.headline: LME copper stops short of $2,300, others mixed.

text.p: LME copper rebounded from a test near the psychological $2,300 per tonne level on Wednesday afternoon, giving a late boost to several other metals.
Successive waves of selling, largely fund liquidation, pressured three month copper prices, which bottomed out at $2,305 before prices bounced on short-covering and trade buying.
The market finished with pared losses of $8 at $2,325, but remained mired below the 30-day moving average of $2,331.
"It's still a bearish close and suggests that we'll come down to fill a gap that extends to $2,295," said analyst Robin Bahr of broker Brandeis.
Nickel joined copper in a modest rally, bouncing off a low of $7,870 to finish the day back above the 30-day moving average and within striking distance of the $8,000 mark.
The market ended with a gain of $80 at $7,985, but needs to move convincingly back above $8,000 before the bearish tone can be dispelled, Bahr said.
"Until we regain the $8,000 level, any rallies will be sold into," he said.
Aluminium also got a minor boost from copper's rebound, prying itself loose of the $1,640 level it had held most of the day to close at its high of $1,647, a gain of $5.
The market was still ensconced between the 10-day and 30-day moving averages, the latter which should offer support at $1,634.
Zinc woke up on the afternoon kerb and marched towards the $1,300 level, topping out $2 shy of the psychological target after earlier in the day extending as low as $1,282.
Last business on the kerb was near the highs at $1,296, up $6.
The market seemed to be consolidating before re-attacking Monday's fresh peak of $1,307, chartists said.
The rallies in the others, however, failed to stimulate lead, pressured by Far Eastern selling after stalling at peaks of $710 for the past two days.
The market, however, clawed off its low of $686 to end $17 weaker at $691.
The move above $700 had been largely option-inspired ahead of Third Wednesday pricing, but now the March date has passed, prices could slide further, Bahr said.
"There may not be anything to hold it up now," he said.
Tin tested the $6,000 level, but managed to remain above it and the 10-day moving average of $5,993.
The afternoon's last trade was at $6,035, a gain of $5.
Alloy ended $5 weaker at $1,540.
--Eric Onstad, London Newsroom +44 171 542-8065
